item.title: [JIRA4202] SQL92 identifiers not quoted before execution via JDBC
item.description:
While trying to add support for the FrontBase SQL 92 compliant database server to JIRA (URL: http://www.frontbase.com/), the following issue is seen:

Database creation and initialization succeeds. During an import of an existing setup (XML import), the following error is displayed: "Form Errors:
Failed to import data. Exception:Error in action: com.atlassian.jira.action.admin.DataImport@692b33, result: null Exception occurred: org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericDataSourceException: SQL Exception while executing the following:SELECT ID, PORTALPAGE, PORTLET_ID, COLUMN_NUMBER, POSITION FROM portletconfiguration (Syntax error 80. Expected '(' not found.)"

The context of the SQL is:

set transaction isolation level serializable, locking pessimistic, read write;
set commit false;
prepare SELECT ID, PORTALPAGE, PORTLET_ID, COLUMN_NUMBER, POSITION FROM portletconfiguration;
commit;
rollback;
set commit true;

Using the SQL tracing facilities of the database, the error is due to the "POSITION" column name, which is a SQL92 reserved identifier for a string function.

The appropriate fix would be to double-quote all column names systematically, in which case even SQL identifiers can be used (e.g, one can have a column called "SELECT")
item.summary: SQL92 identifiers not quoted before execution via JDBC

comments.comment: Same problem is in >= HSQLDB 1.7.2x versions.

A work-around for this is to edit the WEB-INF/classes/entitydefs/entitymodel.xml to change the name of the position column in portletconfiguration (to anything else, like jira_position) and then issue an alter table alter column to change column name in the DB as well.
This bug is also present in JIRA 3.0 Beta

I have raised this as a feature request with the Ofbiz people:

http://jira.undersunconsulting.com/browse/OFBIZ-47

We are a bit stuck at the moment, because we cannot just change the column name without breaking everyone's databases.

Hi Yuri & Jeff,

Yes, I have in fact renamed the "problem" columns as a work around, but the correct solution, as Jeff points out, is to get ofbiz to adhere to the SQL 92 standard. One is supposed to quote all tokens that have the same names as keywords.

Also, I have JIRA working with the FrontBase database (www.frontbase.com) How does one submit the mapping files to Atlassian for inclusion in future releases?

Manu,

Glad you've got it working. Thanks for the offer of the config files. If you could attach the files to the issue online, or mail them to us at jira-support@atlassian.com, we'll include them in the next JIRA release.
Added frontbase db mapping and comments to entityengine.xml with instruction on changing the entitymodel.xml
We haven't actually fixed the main problem in this issue, so I'll reopen this. Frontbase entity files are addressed in JIRA5001.

comments.comment:
I classified this issue as "Blocker" as I am currently setting up JIRA for one of our customers
and I must be able to restrict the issue creation to certain user groups.

Claudia,
I imported your data and could succesfully create a subtask as per your steps.

What I need is the full logs for jira. This should be in the console, just cut and paste the contents. (If you are running JIRA as a Windows Service you will not be able to do this).

Cheers,
Nick

Hello Nick,

I attached the log file as requested. I cut and paste the contents of the console starting from where I tried to create the sub-task and failed.

Ciao,
Claudia

Hi Claudia,

Unfortunately, this is a 'bug' within JIRA - the issue is being tracked at:

http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JIRA7112
http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JIRA7113

In order for this type of condition to work correctly (with a suitable error mesage being displayed rather than an 'ugly'exception as you are observing) on the intial create issue transition, a substantial re-write of the JIRA code would be required. In the short-term, the ability to add a condition to the initial transition from within the editor will be removed.

A possible workaround would be to hard-code a check wrapping the 'Create Sub-Task' operation so as it is only available to the a specific user group. This would involve adding a check such as:

<webwork:if test="/remoteUser/groups/contains('PPC-GROUP') == true">
...
</webwork:if>

to the file:

../includes/panels/issue/operations.jsp

The link to create a sub-task would no longer be available to users who are not members of the specified group.

Regards,
Keith

item.title: [JIRA8328] "required field"-integrity check asks for input even if the field is not displayed on the screen
item.description:
what I have done:

  1. specifiy a field as "required" within the field configuration, e.g. time estimations (German: "Zeiterfassung", see marks within the attachments)
  2. modify the default screen not to contain this field as it will be part of a different screen, attached to a workflow transition
  3. create a new issue by filling out the default screen

result:
this will create an error message, saying that the required field has not been entered ( although it is not visible on the screen and cannot be entered at all ! ) as shown on the attached screen shot

consequence:
It is not possible to create any new issue !
That's very hard to detect, if you are not aware of the system behaviour and will generate a huge amount of internal support calls by the effected users.
item.summary: "required field"-integrity check asks for input even if the field is not displayed on the screen

comments.comment:
JIRA-Admins:
please delete the second attachment (3,61 MB file size), which is unfortunately more or less a duplicate of the first one. I do not have the permission to do this. Thx in advance.

Frank,

Making a field required through Field Configurations, means that this field must always have a value.

Making fields required during creation or a transition has not yet been implemented but is an issue we would like to address.
This issue can be tracked at: JIRA5783
Please vote for this issue.

You can create a Workflow Validator that checks for a value during a transition.
One of our customers has written a validator that does this and can be found at our Jira Community.

Please lett us know if you hae anymore queries.

Cheers,
Nick

item.title: [JIRA2565] Rule-based Notification Schemes
item.description:
Currently, the notification schemes are pretty good - and cover what most people want.

However, what would be very useful is to be able to define some rules for more complex notification schemes.

For example, you may want to notify a particular group on a particular event based on some data in the issue - predicatable data like version, component, value of some custom field.

Something like:

CustomField.Location="London"
Component="Workflow"

-Nick
item.summary: Rule-based Notification Schemes

comments.comment:
I agree - I have users that would like to be able to 'watch' a project component, or project version.

The only alternative that I can find is to setup and subscribe to a filter that looks for all issues created in the past day - and have it sent once a day.

However, this isn't as nice as a new issue event triggered notification. I'm guessing that this could be accomplished via custom tables and a 'create issue' listener

item.title: [JIRA4697] Add custom notification events to support email notification of custom workflow steps
item.description:
It is currently not possible to send email notifications on a custom workflow transition. This makes the custom workflow feature almost not useable.

It would be good to add custom events in notification schemes that map to the custom transitions.
item.summary: Add custom notification events to support email notification of custom workflow steps

comments.comment: You are absolutely right. Currently, we are planning to address this issue in a near future.
For those interested, here's a workaround for JIRA3 while waiting for this feature to arrive: http://blogs.codehaus.org/people/vmassol/archives/000842_writing_a_jira_3_plugin.html

That's an awesome tutorial! Thanks!

Also, please have a look at the linked issue. In JIRA 3.0 final it will be possible to edit the "fire event" function and select which event will be fired (e.g. Issue Resolved, Issue Closed). While you still cannot create cutom events, you have more flexibility in choosing who will be notified in each transition.

At the moment, due to time constraints, we would like to push off the full implementation of custom events until JIRA 3.1. Do you mind if we decrease the priority of this issue to "Major"?
I opened a request for the same thing also. See JIRA5459

Here's a file containing a diff style patch, plus the changed files.

Note:

  • I haven't included JiraWebActionSupport.properties, since the changes are quite small
  • The contents of the email templates are customized for my needs, just replace the text in them with 'Custom Event 1' ect for general deployment.
  • I changed AbstractIssueEventListener so that it by default triggers issueGenericEvent for the custom event types, since the only place I've overriden this is in the MailListener class. All the others can stay as they are which avoids modifying a whole load of other stuff. You may wish to modify the other listeners appropriatly.

It's now easy to add new custom events by editing three files:

1. notification-events.xml - Update the event name and description
2. JiraWebActionSupport.properties - Update the email.issue_customevent1
3. Update the email templates
4. Trigger the user events from your workflow.
Note: The attached patch is against jira 3.2.2.

Chirs,

Thank you very much for contributing the code!

Anton

comments.comment:
Hi,

May I ask if by plugins you mean the JIRA Toolkit available from:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAEXT/JIRA+Toolkit

If so could you please ensure that you are using the 0.6.1 and not 0.6 with 3.4.1?

If you are not using the Toolkit could you please mention what "new plugins" you have installed? Where are they from?

Anton

We installled the JIRA Toolkit and our Search Template drop down box on the creation of new custom fields dissapeared. This was because we installled JIRA Toolkit 0.6.1 on JIRA 3.3.3. After we removed the JIRA Toolkit plugin all seemed well.

Version 0.5.1 is also available for download if you want to install it on ver 3.3.3. And I like their big red note:
"JIRA breaks in interesting ways if you use a newer toolkit version on an older JIRA. Please don't!"

item.title: [JIRA7909] Search/ filter for "empty" fields
item.description:
Our customer's main problem is the following:
How can we filter all Standard Issue Types (or Sub-Task Issue Types), which do not have an Original Estimate yet?

But there are other scenarios where we miss the possibility of searching for fields "that are still empty"
e.g., find all issues where there is no "Fixed in Build" (Text Field (< 255 characters) with Free Text Searcher)
or find all issues where there is no "Release Note" (Free Text Field (unlimited text) with Free Text Searcher)
item.environment: 3.2.2 Enterprise Edition, Build #90 (please refer to the attachment for system info)
item.summary: Search/ filter for "empty" fields

comments.comment: Yes, it's an unfortunate limitation in the search system. For now, a workaround is to sort by the relevant field. The first issues in the search will then be those with empty field values.

We already apply this workaround, but would need to have the search system enhanced.
Is there a feature request on your roadmap that I can vote for? I imagine that we are not the
only JIRA users/ customers requesting this type of search.
I couldn't find an existing issue. I've changed the type of this issue to record it.

I second the motion for allowing one to filter for a NULL Date Due value. I have several shared due date filters set up so staff can see what past due, due this week and due beyond next week. It would be great to be able to have a saved filter to also see what items do not have a due date.

item.description:

item.summary: Export to Excel: Not able to export the description

comments.comment:
I've done this internally. Atlassian seems to be of the opinion that description is not an often asked for column!
Not here
Here's how to customize Excel "All fields" view:
atlassian-jira/secure/views/navigator/navigator-excel.jsp
Add description at line 86 (after summary):
<%-- added description --%>
<td bgcolor=dddddd><b><webwork:text name="/field('description')/nameKey" /></b></td>
and line 126 (after summary):
<%-- added description --%>
<td>
<webwork:property value="string('description')"/>
</td>

Note: my line numbers are based on version 3.2.1 (where you will also have the ability to export all displayed columns with the new "Current Fields" Excel output format.)
Cheers, mate!

Thanks for answering Neal.

In pre 3.2 the excel view is commonly used fields and con not be modified within JIRA itself, you have to make the modification listed above.
As of 3.2 there are 2 excel views. One is the same as before, now know as the "Default View" and the other is the columns that are currently displayed in the Issue Navigator (Current View).

Hope this explains the situation.

Cheers,
Nick

Yesterday I fix in "View Issue Fields" the fields "Priority" and "Description" to "Required".

The "Move Issues" option not work after these changes.

item.title: [JIRA4361] Cannot store workflows of over 4000 characters in Oracle
item.description: Oracle has the infamous problem of not being able to store more than 4000 characters in a VARCHAR2 text field. JIRA 3 stores edited workflows in a VARCHAR2 field, meaning one cannot copy and edit most workflows when using JIRA with Oracle.
item.summary: Cannot store workflows of over 4000 characters in Oracle

comments.comment:
There is a workaround of sorts for this. If a workflow can be constructed on another JIRA instance (eg. JIRA Standalone), then it can be saved to disk, and made known to JIRA by editing WEB-INF/classes/workflows.xml. This is documented at:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/JIRA+3+workflows+in+Oracle
Would it be possible to store the files as lob in the database, instead of varchar2?

Pierre,

It's possible, but I think the problem with LOBs was that the code becomes unportable across different databases. We'll have to investigate.
You solved the problem with comment fields being too big. Isn't that code resuable here?
As far as I know, the comment field is still limited to 4000 characters in Oracle?

Something else that may be (somewhat helpful)... Another bug (feature?) in JIRA allows one to build workflows in an Oracle database and export the XML, even if the WF is larger than 4000 characters.

When you exceed the 4000 char limit, you may notice that returning to your Steps page for your workflow, the item you just added is displayed – as if the data was stored somewhere. So, basically, the cache is out of sync w/ the database. Usually, this is a bad thing, but it can help in this case. Keep editing your workflow and ignoring the error messages, periodically exporting the workflow to XML as you go. As long as the server doesn't get restarted, you can keep working and building your workflow.

Of course, all future modifications must occur directly in the XML, but you can at least get started.

I think we've (at least some helpful users) have found a solution to this - the Oracle 10g driver has an option to allow varchars to be stored as CLOBs (without Oracle-specific code). See:

http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JIRA5297?page=comments#action_28039
